metadata.titleEn: XKS waveform and splitting detection results of compass-elip seismic array (2010-2013)
metadata.description: The reconstruction of the craton by the mantle plume and its subsequent dynamic effects are important scientific issues related to the formation and evolution of the craton. Emeishan Large Igneous Province is located in the western margin of Yangtze craton, which is an ideal window to study the effect of mantle plume on craton reformation. With the support of the national key research and development program "Deep Process and Resource Effect of Important Yanshanian Events" (Grant 2016YFC0600400), the mantle deformation characteristics of Emeishan Large Igneous Province were obtained by using teleseismic shear wave (sks, SKKS and PKS) splitting; Combined with the wave velocity structure, geothermal flow and volcanic rock distribution, it reveals the strengthening effect of mantle plume on the craton and the profound influence of the strengthened lithosphere on the present deep process of the southeastern margin of the Qinghai Tibet Plateau; At the same time, it also provides a new perspective for further understanding the origin of seismic anisotropy at the top of the upper mantle and asthenosphere demonstrator interaction.

background: Tectonic plate motion and mantle convection deform the Earth's mantle, and the resultant orientations of the crystalline lattices of mantle minerals can be inferred from seismic anisotropy (Park & Levin, 2002). Shear-wave splitting of seismic phases converted at the core-mantle boundary (CMB) (such as SKS, SKKS, and PKS, hereinafter referred to as XKS) is used to determine the orientation (inferred from the polarization φ of the fast wave) and the strength (inferred from the delay time δt of the slow wave) of the apparent anisotropy integrated from the CMB to the surface along the raypath and provides insights into the mantle dynamics (Savage, 1999; Silver, 1996). The India-Asia continental collision and shortening in the Cenozoic have driven the lateral extrusion of the Tibetan Plateau along the Ailao Shan–Red River Fault (ARF) in the west Yunnan, SW China (e.g., Chung et al., 1997; Tapponnier et al., 1982) (Figure 1a), and distinct crustal deformations occurred conspicuously across the ARF. Intense E–W shortening occurred to the west of the ARF, and three main sutures (Indus-Yarlung Suture [IYS], Bangong-Nujiang Suture [BNS], and Jinsha Suture [JS]) spanning a width of ∼600 km in central Tibet are shrunken into a narrow zone of ∼200 km in the Three-River Orogenic Zone (TRZ) (Figure 1a).
research objective: To address these questions, we performed shear-wave splitting analysis using data from a dense linear E–W trending seismic array (COMPASS-ELIP) across the west Yunnan. Seismic anisotropic features identified in this study provide evidence for the interaction between the Cenozoic Tibetan mantle flow and the western Yangtze Craton. At the same time, they yield new insights into the nature of seismic anisotropy in the lithosphere–asthenosphere transition when integrated with geological observations.
methods: The COMPASS-ELIP seismic array was deployed nearly along ∼27°N latitude with the profile length of ∼850 km and average station spacing of ∼15 km. Data from 58 broadband seismic stations of the experiment are processed in this study after removing the instrument responses (Reftek-130 dataloggers and Güralp CMG-3ESP seismometers with the frequency range from 30/60 s to 50 Hz). In this study, we conduct a surface wave polarization analysis to estimate possible sensor misorientations (Baker & Stevens, 2004; Stachnik et al., 2012). After the sensor orientation correction, waveforms from events with Mw ≥ 5.5 at epicentral distances of 85°–180°, which include all XKS phases sufficiently, are selected and band-pass filtered in 0.04–0.5 Hz to enhance the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) for the following analysis (Gao & Liu, 2009). We use the SplitLab software package to perform the shear-wave splitting analysis for each XKS phase which can be distinguished clearly in the waveforms (Wüstefeld et al., 2008). Based on reliable splitting measurements, we calculate the station-averaged splitting by stacking the normalized energy maps of individual XKS analysis from the SC method (Wolfe & Silver, 1998), and a statistical F test is conducted to obtain the 95% confidence interval (Silver & Chan, 1991) as a proxy for the corresponding errors (Figure S3).
dataset: Data from 58 broadband seismic stations of the experiment are processed in this study after removing the instrument responses (Reftek-130 dataloggers and Güralp CMG-3ESP seismometers with the frequency range from 30/60 s to 50 Hz).
findings: One of the most prominent features in our result is a N–S-oriented strong anisotropic zone (stations E14–E19) that appears abruptly between the TRZ and the INZ of the Emeishan LIP, exhibiting a maximum δt of ∼1.5 s in the center that delays to ∼0.5 s on the flanks. Therefore, the spatial correlation of potassic magmatism and strong mantle anisotropy lends the strong supports to the interaction between the southward mantle flow in the asthenosphere, associated with the Cenozoic continental extrusion of the Tibetan Plateau, and the plume-strengthened lithosphere beneath the westernmost Yangtze Craton.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method for measuring seismic anisotropy in the Earth's mantle?
Example.Answer: One data collection method involves deploying a dense linear seismic array, such as the COMPASS-ELIP, across a geological region of interest. This method includes using broadband seismic stations equipped with Reftek-130 dataloggers and Güralp CMG-3ESP seismometers, which capture seismic waveforms from events with magnitudes Mw ≥ 5.5 at epicentral distances of 85°–180°.

Example.Question: What is an example of a technique used to enhance the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) in seismic data analysis?
Example.Answer: An example of a technique to enhance SNR is band-pass filtering seismic waveforms in the frequency range of 0.04–0.5 Hz, as done in the analysis of waveforms from XKS phases. This filtering helps clarify the seismic signals for further analysis, such as shear-wave splitting.

Example.Question: Please provide an example of how sensor misorientations are corrected in seismic data collection.
Example.Answer: Sensor misorientations in seismic data collection can be corrected using surface wave polarization analysis, as exemplified in the COMPASS-ELIP seismic array study. This analysis helps to estimate and adjust the orientation of the sensors to ensure accurate data collection.

Definition.Question: What does 'broadband seismic station' refer to in the context of seismic data collection and analysis?
Definition.Answer: A broadband seismic station refers to a setup that includes equipment capable of recording a wide range of seismic frequencies, typically using instruments like Reftek-130 dataloggers and Güralp CMG-3ESP seismometers, which are used to capture seismic data over a frequency range from 30/60 seconds to 50 Hz.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of 'surface wave polarization analysis' in correcting sensor orientations?
Definition.Answer: Surface wave polarization analysis is used to estimate and correct possible sensor misorientations in seismic data collection. This ensures accurate recording of seismic waves by correcting the orientation of sensors, which is crucial for enhancing the reliability of subsequent analyses such as shear-wave splitting.

Comparison.Question: How does the data collection method using a dense linear seismic array compare to other seismic data collection techniques in terms of capturing mantle anisotropy?
Comparison.Answer: The data collection method using the COMPASS-ELIP seismic array involves deploying stations nearly along a specific latitude with a defined spacing, focusing on capturing shear-wave splitting to study mantle anisotropy. This approach is detailed in the field, emphasizing its ability to provide insights into mantle dynamics through broadband seismic stations. In contrast, other techniques may not use such dense spatial coverage or specific shear-wave analysis, potentially impacting the resolution and detail of anisotropic features captured.

Interpretation.Question: How might the deployment and configuration of seismic stations in a linear E–W trending array influence the interpretation of seismic anisotropy in the region?
Interpretation.Answer: The deployment of seismic stations in a linear E–W trending array allows for detailed analysis of seismic anisotropic features and offers evidence for the interaction between mantle flows and craton structures. The configuration helps in assessing the anisotropy strength and orientation, which is critical for understanding lithosphere-asthenosphere interactions.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can the integration of seismic anisotropy data with geological observations enhance the understanding of the lithosphere-asthenosphere transition?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrating seismic anisotropy data with geological observations provides a comprehensive view of the lithosphere-asthenosphere transition. It yields new insights into the nature of seismic anisotropy and helps in understanding the crust-mantle interactions, which are pivotal for elucidating the processes influencing the region's tectonic evolution.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes discrepancies in the measurement of seismic anisotropy across different stations in a dataset?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Discrepancies can arise from sensor misorientations, which are addressed through surface wave polarization analysis to estimate and correct possible sensor misorientations. Additionally, variations in the local geological structures or mantle flow can contribute to differences in seismic anisotropy measurements.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it important to use a specific frequency range when filtering seismic data during data collection?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Using a specific frequency range, such as 0.04–0.5 Hz, is crucial to enhance the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) for seismic wave analysis. This filtering helps in isolating the relevant seismic phases (such as XKS) and improving the clarity and reliability of the data for subsequent analysis.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the causes behind the selection of certain epicentral distances and magnitudes in seismic data collection methods?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Epicentral distances of 85°–180° and magnitudes of Mw ≥ 5.5 are selected to ensure all XKS phases are sufficiently included and to capture significant seismic events that provide clear waveforms for analysis. This selection helps in obtaining reliable shear-wave splitting measurements necessary for understanding mantle dynamics.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of utilizing shear-wave splitting analysis on seismic data collected from a dense linear seismic array in understanding mantle dynamics?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing shear-wave splitting analysis on seismic data from a dense linear seismic array can provide evidence for the interaction between mantle flow and a craton, yielding insights into the nature of seismic anisotropy in the lithosphere-asthenosphere transition.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the selection of seismic events with specific magnitude and epicentral distances impact the findings related to mantle anisotropy?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Selecting seismic events with magnitude ≥ 5.5 and epicentral distances of 85°–180° ensures that all XKS phases are sufficiently included, which enhances the signal-to-noise ratio, thereby allowing clear differentiation of waveforms and reliable measurement of shear-wave splitting, revealing strong anisotropic zones and interaction with mantle flows.

Causal Consequence.Question: What effects might arise from addressing sensor misorientations in data collection methods on the reliability of seismic anisotropy measurements?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Addressing sensor misorientations in data collection methods can improve the accuracy of seismic anisotropy measurements, ensuring reliable splitting measurements which are crucial for calculating station-averaged splitting and understanding mantle dynamics, as reflected by the statistical confidence intervals obtained.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedures for ensuring sensor orientation accuracy during the deployment of a seismic array for mantle deformation studies?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: A surface wave polarization analysis is conducted to estimate possible sensor misorientations. After this analysis, waveforms are corrected for sensor orientation errors to ensure data accuracy.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is shear-wave splitting analysis conducted using data from seismic stations to study mantle dynamics?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Shear-wave splitting analysis is conducted using the SplitLab software package for each XKS phase distinguished in the waveforms. The procedure involves band-pass filtering waveforms from events with sufficient magnitude and epicentral distance, followed by calculating station-averaged splitting by stacking normalized energy maps and conducting a statistical F test for confidence intervals.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What steps are involved in processing seismic data from broadband stations to analyze mantle anisotropy?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The steps involve removing instrument responses from the data collected at broadband stations, selecting waveforms from suitable seismic events, band-pass filtering to enhance the signal-to-noise ratio, and performing shear-wave splitting analysis to determine seismic anisotropy characteristics.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of specific seismic data enable the understanding of mantle dynamics and lithosphere-asthenosphere interaction?
Enablement.Answer: Shear-wave splitting analysis using data from a dense seismic array provides evidence of seismic anisotropic features, offering insights into mantle flow dynamics and the nature of seismic anisotropy in the lithosphere-asthenosphere transition.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the detection and analysis of shear-wave splitting in seismic studies?
Enablement.Answer: The use of SplitLab software to perform shear-wave splitting analysis, alongside the deployment of broadband seismic stations and advanced data processing techniques like surface wave polarization analysis, enables the detection and analysis of shear-wave splitting in seismic studies.

Expectation.Question: Why might data from broadband seismic stations require specific preprocessing steps before analysis?
Expectation.Answer: Data from broadband seismic stations need preprocessing to remove instrument responses and correct any sensor misorientations to ensure accurate shear-wave splitting analysis and enhance the signal-to-noise ratio for reliable results.

Judgmental.Question: What challenges might arise in the accurate processing of seismic data from broadband stations, and how can these be addressed according to methodologies used in the field?
Judgmental.Answer: Challenges in processing seismic data include ensuring correct sensor orientations and enhancing signal-to-noise ratios. These can be addressed by conducting surface wave polarization analysis to estimate sensor misorientations and applying band-pass filtering to improve SNR for analysis.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways could the methods used for data collection in the COMPASS-ELIP study be refined or expanded to enhance understanding of mantle anisotropy and related geological phenomena?
Judgmental.Answer: Refinements could include increasing the density of seismic stations for more detailed spatial resolution, employing additional geophysical methods like magnetotellurics, and integrating more extensive geological datasets to better correlate seismic anisotropy with surface geological features.
